See the problem with nerds like this explaining anything is they use terms that to them are more smart or accurate but to others they just obfuscate meaning and thus remove any input those "others" may have had based off pure ego driven  semantics.  What I'm referring to here is this "fashion gurus" use of the word "septillion".  See to me a word is as useful as how effectively it communicates it's meaning to, in most cases, to the most ppl.  In this case made up words like "gazillion" would be more effective at recruiting the lost brain powerto the cause.  Sadly science nerds like to be uber specific and this alienate any other "non-science" input by simply postulating in a way that makes them sound right it smart rather than communicating ideas.  It's a terrible dichotomy embodied by individuals who argue semantics almost exclusively from an academia perspective.  This however is not capable of educating others or enlightening yourself to new ways of looked ng at things

So gravity could be considered a super fluid, the fact that more massive objects are more affected could be explained in a similar way of the formation of beads of none miscible liquids at the boundary, which favour the formation and coalesence of larger spheres. Imagine if you were floating at the top of a frictionless lake (tho the concept is null because you couldn't float if it were frictionless). You wouldn't be able to swim through it. If you were at rest, you'd be stuck floating there. You could move your arms through it to try to create thrust but you'd meet no resistance. The only way you could save yourself is if you were to throw something, like maybe your hat or a watch. Thanks to Newton's third law, this would create an extremely tiny force that would begin to push you, and you would continue at this incredibly slow speed until you reached a shore since no friction would ever slow you down, assuming we neglect the air

Please correct me if I am wrong, but absolute zero is a theoretical point, not an actual temperature.  Due to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, it does not exist because you cannot define a position and a velocity exactly, and the velocity is relative to the particle's energy. Something you said about how every atom begins to move together when they are in the same energy state has a macro scale analog. Start a ton of metronomes on a moveable platform and they will work themselves into synchronicity (plenty of vids of this), and you can consider the 'orbit', vector and position of all of the electrons in the superfluid to likewise synchronize quickly.

Even though an electron's mass is a MUCH smaller than a metronome's weight, they are cycling at around how many millions or billions of times per second? This makes up for the disparity in mass by a lot.

Why do people have so much trouble with goddamn kelvin?!?!? Say "zero kelvins", or "two kelvins". It's an SI unit, not a type of degree. Don't EVER say "degrees kelvin". And think about it: there's "one kelvin", and that's it. Everything else is "__ kelvins". Just pretend you're saying volts, or joules, or seconds, or metres... Same idea.

I discovered this theory about 20 years ago, you dont need any fancy equipment to see this in action right before your eyes, buy shrimp maruchan/nissin top ramen, put it in a deep pot, boil it with some water, and empty the seasonings that come with it and stir for 2 minutes, turn the stove off, empty the noodles with liquids into a clear pyrex, and slightly tilt it from side to side and you will see some super fluids climb up the sides about 1-1.5 inches above the level of the broth and it will try to stay 1-1.5 inches above the broth as you move tilt the bowl. Thumbs up if you have seen this in action before or if you tried it and saw it work 😎👍🏻

I know about the whole discrete energy levels thing, but when a particle transitions to another energy level, what does that look like? Or does the particle really just jump, in an apparent instant, from one state to the next?  Or are the possible states generally so numerous that on a macroscopic level, they appear smooth and continuous even if they are really making, for all intents and purposes, quantum leaps?
